ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Displays simple statistics, correlations among the input variables, the confidence 
limits for the regression coefficients, and the canonical redundancy analysis.
Produces raw regression coefficients from the regression analyses.

Produces the 95% confidence limits for the regression coefficients from the 
regression analyses.
Produces correlations among the original variables.
Produces correlations among the regression coefficient estimates.

[Syntax: DATA=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the SAS data set to be analyzed by PROC CANCORR.

[Syntax: EDF=error-df] 
      
Specifies the error degrees of freedom if the input observations are residuals 
from a regression analysis.

Requests that statistics for the intercept be included when B, CLB, SEB, T, or PROBT 
is specified for the regression analyses.
Specifies the method of evaluating the multivariate test statistics.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the multivariate tests are evaluated using the usual approximations based  on the F distribution.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Computes exact p-values for three of the four tests (Wilks’ lambda, the Hotelling-Lawley  trace, and Roy’s greatest root) and an improved F approximation for the fourth (Pillai’s  trace).

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: NCAN=number] 
      
Specifies the number of canonical variables for which full output is desired.
Omits the intercept from the canonical correlation and regression models.

Suppresses the display of all output. Note that this option temporarily disables 
the Output Delivery System (ODS).

[Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set] 
      
Creates an output SAS data set to contain all the original data plus scores on the 
canonical variables.

[Syntax: OUTSTAT=SAS-data-set] 
      
Creates an output SAS data set containing various statistics, including the
canonical correlations and coefficients and the multiple regression statistics 
you request.

Produces partial correlations between regressors and dependent variables, removing 
from each dependent variable and regressor the effects of all other regressors.
Produces probability levels for the t statistics in the regression analyses.

[Syntax: RDF=regression-df] 
      
Specifies the regression degrees of freedom if the input observations are residuals 
from a regression analysis.
Produces canonical redundancy statistics.

[Syntax: PARPREFIX=name] 
      
Specifies a prefix for naming the residual variables in the OUT= data set and the
OUTSTAT= data set.
Produces standard errors of the regression coefficients.

Suppresses all default output from the canonical analysis except the tables of canonical 
correlations and multivariate statistics.
Produces means and standard deviations.

[Syntax: SINGULAR=p] 
      
Specifies the singularity criterion, where 0 < p < 1.
Produces squared multiple correlations and F tests for the regression analyses.

Produces semipartial correlations between regressors and dependent variables, 
removing from each regressor the effects of all other regressors.

Produces squared partial correlations between regressors and dependent variables, 
removing from each dependent variable and regressor the effects of all other regressors.

Produces squared semipartial correlations between regressors and dependent variables, 
removing from each regressor the effects of all other regressors.
Produces standardized regression coefficients.
Produces t statistics for the regression coefficients.

Requests multiple regression analyses with the VAR variables as dependent variables 
and the WITH Variables as regressors.

[Syntax: VNAME=label] 
      
Specifies a character constant to refer to variables from the VAR statement 
in the output. Enclose the constant in single or double quotes.

[Syntax: VPREFIX=name] 
      
Specifies a prefix for naming canonical variables from the VAR statement.

Requests multiple regression analyses with the WITH variables as dependent variables 
and the VAR variables as regressors.

[Syntax: WNAME=label] 
      
Specifies a character constant to refer to variables in the WITH statement in the 
output. Enclose the constant in single or double quotes.

[Syntax: WPREFIX=name] 
      
Specifies a prefix for naming canonical variables from the WITH statement.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: PARTIAL variables ;
      
You can use the PARTIAL statement to base the canonical analysis on partial correlations.

Syntax: BY <DESCENDING> variable-1 <...<DESCENDING> variable-n> <NOTSORTED>; 
      
Obtains separate analyses on observations in groups defined by the BY variables.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that 
immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.
Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: FREQ variable;
      
If one variable in your data set represents the frequency of occurrence for the other 
values in the observation, specify the variable’s name in a FREQ statement. PROC CANCORR 
then treats the data set as if each observation appears ni times, where ni is the value 
of the FREQ variable for observation i.
